citations.narrative:
On 4/16/2024, one adult female ostrich died at the facility after being hit by a vehicle. The facility conducts "drive-thru"
monster truck tours inside a large, multi-species enclosure. During one of these tours, the driver noticed the ostrich in the
road and honked the horn for it to move out of the way before proceeding. Due to the poor visibility at the front of the
vehicle, the driver did not realize the ostrich had moved back into the road and it was killed.
Inadequate handling or protection from vehicles entering an animal's enclosure can lead to severe injury or death. All
animals shall be handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating,
excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
To be corrected from this day, 4/29/2024, forward.

Three adult rabbits are currently being housed in an enclosure with two emu, seven chickens, two capybara, three
kangaroos, and three guineafowl.
Housing rabbits with other species may result in injury to the rabbits. Rabbits must not be housed in the same primary
enclosure with any other species for their health and safety.
To be corrected by 5/3/2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On 4/16/2024, one adult female ostrich died at the facility after being hit by a vehicle. The facility conducts "drive-thru" 
monster truck tours inside a large, multi-species enclosure. During one of these tours, the driver noticed the ostrich in the 
road and honked the horn for it to move out of the way before proceeding. Due to the poor visibility at the front of the 
vehicle, the driver did not realize the ostrich had moved back into the road and it was killed. 
Inadequate handling or protection from vehicles entering an animal's enclosure can lead to severe injury or death. All 
animals shall be handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, 
excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
To be corrected from this day, 4/29/2024, forward. 
3.58(a) 
   
Classification and separation. 
Three adult rabbits are currently being housed in an enclosure with two emu, seven chickens, two capybara, three 
kangaroos, and three guineafowl.  
Housing rabbits with other species may result in injury to the rabbits. Rabbits must not be housed in the same primary 
enclosure with any other species for their health and safety.  
To be corrected by 5/3/2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
